awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Livelihood Strategies at Classic and Colonial Period Tahcabo, Yucatan, Mexico
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will study the impacts of macro-governance changes such as colonialism on the activities of farmers in rural communities. In studies of contemporary agriculture, researchers strive to understand how people choose livelihood strategies and to infer the long-term implications of their decisions for regional political stability, economic security, and landscape sustainability. Archaeological research is well-positioned to contribute to knowledge about the impact rural farmers can have in these realms due to its focus on behavioral and environmental changes over extended time frames. Within this broader context, this project will generate an agricultural history for the research site, including an account of the activities pursued and crops grown through time, focusing on periods of high population density. The study will provide training to graduate-level students from the United States as well as undergraduate students from Mexico. It will generate collaborations between laboratory scientists in the United States, Canada, and Mexico. Research results will be disseminated through publications written for broad audiences in more than one language and the installation of an exhibit in the museum of the community that will host the research. Community residents will be made aware of food production strategies employed in the past that could prove useful for them today.

Archaeological research has focused on large political centers, while extant historical records primarily tell the stories of elites. Recent studies have begun to address daily lives and household economies. This project shifts attention to farmers and their strategies given regional constraints and opportunities. It will study whether past peoples living in the rural community of Tahcabo diversified their economic activities or pursued specialized production of particular goods or crops during times of population growth spanning the Early Classic (AD 200-500), Late Classic (AD 600-900), and Colonial (AD 1550-1800) periods. Excavations will take place in houses and gardens from these time periods in order to locate evidence for the economic activities conducted by household. Analysis of soil samples for microscopic plant remains will provide information on the crops grown through time. Chronological information about the occupation of each house will be determined through the study of ceramic styles and the dating of charred wood. Using these lines of evidence, the project will test propositions about the strategies employed by farmers before and after Spanish colonization. The results will provide new insights into the relationship between social and agricultural change.

por.por_cntn:
Maia Dedrick has completed research for her dissertation: Colonial Period Livelihoods at Tahcabo, Yucatan, Mexico, supported by the NSF Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. During her funding period, she spent four months conducting archaeological excavations in Yucatan, Mexico, followed by a three-month lab season to study artifacts and process soil samples for analysis. After a semester isolating and identifying micro-remains of plants from tools and sediment at McMaster University, she returned to the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill for the study of charred wood and seeds, followed by additional study and community outreach in Tahcabo, Yucatan, during the summer of 2018. As an archaeologist of the Colonial period, Dedrick was interested in understanding how colonialism impacted the daily lives of farmers, and what livelihood strategies rural populations selected as they sought to cope with wider changes. In particular, she focused on the artifacts and plant and animal remains from houses and gardens that would provide evidence for varied economic activities and compared their diversity and density through time.

Dedrick accomplished the goal of her research, finding that marginalized farmers at Tahcabo during the early Colonial period sought strategies that would allow them to maintain flexibility and mobility in case conditions deteriorated. For example, they hunted and gathered in the forest and grew plants that would quickly provide harvests. During the late Colonial period, populations began to engage in wage labor, tended plants and animals in their gardens, and focused on opportunities for food sharing across the community.

This research provides new insights into how households adapt to political and economic change, building on frameworks from rural development studies to contribute to broader understandings of how farmers make economic decisions, and how their actions relate to the sustainability of environments, livelihoods, and institutions. The work shows that agriculture has not gone on unchanged in Yucatan but instead has fluctuated through time. Apart from this, the findings demonstrate the importance of low areas on the landscape called rejolladas, providing evidence for their use over the past 3,000 years for both gardening and rituals.

Throughout the research project, Dedrick shared results with contemporary residents of Tahcabo through presentations, site tours, and workshops. Engagement activities and temporary exhibits took place at the local community museum. In addition, many town residents including high school students learned about archaeology by working with the project, and they were joined by local university students and people with training in archaeology from around the world who also built their skills through project participation.
